Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: The coordinator emailed a brief suggestion about organizing supplies a different way if time allows.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the text from my boyfriend. He sounded upset, thinking I’d forgotten our weekend plans, when really, I’d just misunderstood the time. I knew I should call him right away, clear things up before it turned into a bigger issue. That’s what a good girlfriend would do—resolve conflicts quickly, not let them fester. But just as I was about to dial, my email pinged. It was the volunteer coordinator, suggesting we reorganize the supply closet if we had a spare moment today. I was already at the community center, and I knew she expected me to follow her instructions, even if it wasn’t urgent. I could feel the pressure building—my boyfriend needed reassurance, but the coordinator counted on me to be reliable and responsive. I stood in the hallway, phone in one hand, email open on the other, torn between smoothing things over with him and proving myself as a dependable volunteer. My heart raced as I weighed which expectation to meet first, feeling the tug of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
